qc.notes: All core poses present; good focus and neutral lighting; no filters/heavy makeup.

skin_type.label: combination
skin_type.rationale: T-zone shows more visible pores (nose/medial cheeks) while jawline and perioral areas look smoother and less oily; no flaking noted.

skin_tone_fitzpatrick.label: IV
skin_tone_fitzpatrick.note: Estimated from mid-brown appearance in indirect daylight; camera white balance can shift perceived tone.

skin_age_range.rationale: Minimal fine lines and generally smooth texture with mild under-eye contrast; low UV signs align with late-30s appearance.

analysis.overview_explanation: Healthy skin with smooth texture overall. T-zone pores and blackheads on the nose are the most visible features, with mild under-eye darkness and a few cheek spots. Wrinkles and inflammatory acne are minimal.

pores.rationale_plain: Small–medium pores are most visible on the nose and extend slightly to medial cheeks. Forehead and jawline remain fine-pored.
possible_causes: T-zone oil production keeps pores more visible.
Humidity and product residue can accumulate in pores.
Genetics determine baseline pore size and visibility.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Pore prominence clusters on the nose and inner cheeks.
likely_causes: Residue build-up from sunscreen or makeup.
care_education: Cleanse gently twice daily.
Use a salicylic acid (0.5–2%) leave-on 3–5×/week.
Apply daily broad-spectrum SPF to support pore appearance.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Tight groupings of visible openings on the nose.
care_education: Consider a weekly clay mask (1–2×/week).
Use non-comedogenic moisturiser.
Avoid aggressive scrubbing that can inflame.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Dark-centered dots on the nose suggest blackheads.
care_education: Introduce a BHA or retinoid gradually at night.
Double-cleanse on high-SPF or makeup days.
Use SPF daily to protect skin while using actives.

citations.title: AI grading of enlarged pores (Dermatol Ther, 2024)

pores.uncertainty_notes: Pore visibility varies with time since cleansing and lighting.

wrinkles.rationale_plain: Only faint superficial lines on the forehead are visible at rest; periorbital areas look smooth.
possible_causes: Intrinsic aging produces fine lines over time.
UV exposure can accelerate lines, though current exposure is low.
Temporary dehydration can exaggerate fine lines.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Shallow forehead lines seen at rest.
care_education: Daily SPF to slow photoaging.
Consider a gentle, gradual retinoid at night.
Use humectants and barrier-supporting moisturisers.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Dynamic lines not fully testable without expression images.
care_education: Maintain sun protection including sunglasses.
Retinoid routine may help over time.

wrinkles.uncertainty_notes: No smiling/frowning poses; dynamic wrinkles under-estimated.

pigmentation.rationale_plain: A few small, mild-contrast spots on both cheeks and along the jaw; no strong symmetric patches.
possible_causes: Marks left after small blemishes or irritation.
Intermittent past sun exposure can leave discrete spots.
Friction from masks or glasses may contribute on central face.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Discrete macules that can follow healed blemishes.
likely_causes: Minor acne or irritation in the past.
care_education: Daily SPF to prevent darkening.
Gentle brighteners such as azelaic acid or niacinamide; consider vitamin C.
Avoid picking to reduce new marks.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Isolated speckles compatible with cumulative sun.
care_education: Broad-spectrum SPF and hats.
Night retinoid to support even tone over time.

pigmentation.uncertainty_notes: Lighting/white balance can change the appearance of contrast.

redness.rationale_plain: Mild central facial redness most visible at the nose with faint warmth on the cheeks.
possible_causes: Heat, spicy food, or skincare actives can cause transient redness.
Friction from masks or glasses.
Baseline vascular visibility in some areas.

care_education: Use gentle, fragrance-low products.
Daily SPF and avoid harsh scrubs.
Barrier-supporting moisturiser.
Identify/avoid individual triggers.

redness.uncertainty_notes: Redness varies with temperature, exercise, and skincare timing.

texture.rationale_plain: Surface looks mostly smooth with a fine grain, slightly more uneven around the nose and medial cheeks.
possible_causes: Dead-skin and sebum build-up around the T-zone.
Humidity/product layering without thorough cleansing.
Gradual collagen/elastin changes with age.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Most regions are smooth and even.
care_education: Maintain a gentle cleanse-moisturise-SPF routine.
Avoid over-exfoliating which can disrupt barrier.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Fine grain near the nose/medial cheeks.
care_education: Introduce BHA or PHA 2–3×/week.
Pair with ceramide moisturiser to protect barrier.

texture.uncertainty_notes: Texture is sensitive to light direction; front-lit shots can reduce visible relief.

acne.rationale_plain: No inflammatory lesions are visible; multiple blackhead-like comedones appear on the nose.
possible_causes: T-zone oil and keratin plug formation.
Occlusion or friction on the nose.
Hormonal variations that intermittently affect pores.

care_education: Introduce a nightly BHA or adapalene gradually.
Avoid picking to reduce PIH risk.
Use daily SPF to protect while using actives.

acne.uncertainty_notes: Acne fluctuates; current images reflect one point in time.

under_eye.rationale_plain: Both lower lids show clear but modest darkening relative to the cheek without prominent puffiness.
possible_causes: Thin lower-lid skin with visible vessels.
Genetic pigment patterns in Fitzpatrick IV.
Sleep/allergy/dehydration can transiently worsen appearance.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Hue/contrast-based darkness rather than patchy pigment.
likely_causes: Underlying vessels visible through thin skin.
care_education: Daily eye-safe sunscreen.
Try caffeine/cooling eye gels for temporary improvement.
Consult a clinician if long-standing or bothersome.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Consistent tone difference vs cheek suggests some pigment component.
care_education: Use gentle brighteners suitable for peri-orbital use (e.g., niacinamide/azelaic acid).
Avoid rubbing and remove eye makeup gently.
Daily SPF to prevent further darkening.

citations.title: Photonumeric scale for infraorbital dark circles

under_eye.uncertainty_notes: Shadowing from camera angle can affect apparent depth of dark circles.

region_summaries.summary_plain: Fine, shallow lines with overall smooth texture; small pores evenly distributed.
Calm area with minimal lines and small pores; slight warmth of color only.
Mild darkness without puffiness; skin surface looks smooth.
Similar mild darkness and smooth texture as the left side.
Mostly smooth with mild grain near the nose and a few tiny spots.
Matches the left cheek: mild grain medially and scattered small spots.
Most pore-prominent area with multiple blackhead-like dots and mild redness.
Even color and texture; no prominent lines.
Smooth with small pores; no inflammatory lesions noted.
Smoothest area with fine pores; a couple of faint speckles only.
Smooth and even; similar to left jawline.

limitations: Single session; oiliness/redness vary by time of day and routine.
No dynamic expression images to grade movement lines.
RGB photos only; no device colorimetry or dermoscopic detail.
